In war there are no good guys and bad guys, just soldiers who play to win. Now let's look at socialism in Asia and see how it turned out. Now let me get into my real point. Almost every conflict is more or less about resources or markets and not morals. My case and point is the most recent Iraqi war with Sadam Hussein dying and all. Throughout much of the Cold War into the 1970s and 80s he was our staunch ally. We had sold him discreetly WMDs during the Iran Contra affair. The Iranians and Iraqis used WMDs sold to them by the US. When you here about WMDs we knew for certain he had chemical weapons that qualified, we probably had the receipts lying around. It wasn't really a fight over his WMDs we sold him, we knew he wasn't really a problem with that. We also knew that his brutal human rights violations go back a long time, we didn't care. We knew his party had direct ties to the Nazis and that his uncle who was Sadam's mentor had strong ties with Hitler in WW2. We fought with Iraq over oil. More specifically he wanted to move toward a European currency system and exchange, in order to secure our European markets and continue making a stupid profit we went to war and ended up killing Sadam. I guess you could say we were good for toppling him, but we knew about him for years and had helped create some of his problems. In the end wars aren't about good or bad, it's how we decide to view them later.
